comments.content: As a developer myself, everyplace I've worked our code goes thru QA. This is a normal process and while I can unit test. Only a QA can test in a real environment.

discussion.content:
Description
Quality assurance (QA) is a way of preventing mistakes and defects in manufactured products and avoiding problems when delivering products or services to customers; which ISO 9000 defines as "part of quality management focused on providing confidence that quality requirements will be fulfilled".

D. Submit the application to QA before releasing it.
Quality assurance (QA) is any systematic process of determining whether a product or service meets specified requirements. QA establishes and maintains set requirements for developing or manufacturing reliable products.
D. Submit the application to QA before releasing it.

choices.D: Submit the application to QA before releasing it.
choices.A: Limit the use of third-party libraries.

questions.question_text: The IT department's on-site developer has been with the team for many years. Each time an application is released, the security team is able to identify multiple vulnerabilities. Which of the following would BEST help the team ensure the application is ready to be released to production?

In a lessons-learned report, it is suspected that a well-organized, well-funded, and extremely sophisticated group of attackers may have been responsible for a breach at a nuclear facility. Which of the following describes the type of actors that may have been implicated?

discussion.content: i dont mind the repeats. i get to confirm my knowledge
So, is there a main deference between APT and Nation-state threat?

questions.question_text: The Chief Security Officer (CSO) at a major hospital wants to implement SSO to help improve security in the environment and protect patient data, particularly at shared terminals. The Chief Risk Officer (CRO) is concerned that training and guidance have not been provided to frontline staff, and a risk analysis has not been performed. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the CRO's concerns?

discussion.content: SSO works based upon a trust relationship set up between an application, known as the service provider, and an identity provider, like OneLogin. This trust relationship is often based upon a certificate that is exchanged between the identity provider and the service provider. This certificate can be used to sign identity information that is being sent from the identity provider to the service provider so that the service provider knows it is coming from a trusted source. In SSO, this identity data takes the form of tokens which contain identifying bits of information about the user like a userâ€™s email address or a username.

choices.B: SSO would reduce password fatigue, but staff would still need to remember more complex passwords.
choices.D: SSO would reduce the resilience and availability of systems if the identity provider goes offline.
choices.C: SSO would reduce the password complexity for frontline staff.
choices.A: SSO would simplify username and password management, making it easier for hackers to guess accounts.

questions.question_text: Which of the following control types are alerts sent from a SIEM fulfilling based on vulnerability signatures?

An attacker is attempting to harvest user credentials on a client's website. A security analyst notices multiple attempts of random usernames and passwords.
When the analyst types in a random username and password, the logon screen displays the following message:
//IMG//

Which of the following should the analyst recommend be enabled?

discussion.content: Error handling. The website is giving out information after an error has occurred that the threat actor can use to refine their attacks.

Selected Answer: D
Username lockout: This is the most effective measure to thwart credential stuffing attacks. Here's how it works:

Threshold: After a certain number of failed login attempts (typically 3-5) within a specified timeframe, the account is locked.
Duration: The lockout period can vary, often lasting 15-30 minutes or longer.
Reset: Users can typically reset their password or contact support to unlock their account.

According to the CompTIA book, the answer should be C:
"Improper error handling: When software is not designed to properly
handle errors, the result might be release of message and diagnostic
information that is sensitive to the inner workings of the systems. This data
can disclose details to an end user and allow an attacker to gain sufficient
information to advance an attack."

Selected Answer: B
the answer is B.
Error handling isn't something you "enable" lol

comments.content: True, it should be D according to me as A and B doesn't make any sense in this scenario

discussion.content: and I can't determine if its D or C

is username lockout the same as account lockout? "Account lockout keeps the account secure by preventing anyone or anything from guessing the username and password." so if that is the case then i would go with D.
